ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Speaking in Chinese, Chinese culture and history, film techniques.

This course allowed me to improve my Chinese in a way I was not expecting. Each movie had it's own unique motif to it and this class allowed me to really focus on the details and methods used in creating the movie.
Ability to learn Chinese through watching movies and in class exercises.
improved reading, writing, and speaking ability in Chinese; learned about a variety of topics related to Chinese culture, history, and more
A greater appreciation for chinese cinema and culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Very interesting movies, good discussions, relatively easy L5 credit.
Weaknesses: Backened workload, multiple large projects due in very similar times near the end of the semester.
All wonderful! Loved this class, definitely recommend.

strengths: a lot of collaborations
weaknesses: the timing!

Strengths: Very engaging, a lot of group projects so you can always split the workload. 

Weaknesses: Movies have to be watched outside of class time, but if you enjoy watching movies this shouldnt be a problem.

strengths: well-organized and designed based on student feedback, good for students who prefer a self-directed learning style and a fun way to maintain and improve Chinese level for heritage speakers and connect with culture

weaknesses: relatively new course so still in the process of optimizing course design through trial and error, but instructor is very receptive to student feedback and implements quickly

Strengths: You will have a lot of freedom to explore what chinese and chinese culture means to you in this class. Professor Liang is also very diligent about receiving student feedback to help her tailor the class to match the chinese abilities of her students. It is also a very interesting take on learning chinese! 
Weaknesses: could use more organization in facilitating out of class group work. Some assignments are posted a day before they are due without advance notice, although Professor Liang is lenient about deadlines in such cases.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Great way to learn Chinese while not being too encumbered by the difficulty of a normal L5 Chinese class. I was always excited to go to class!

Yes! Super fun, super lovely. Only warning is that daily assignments can be a little scary, especially since they change from time to time from the beginning-of-term original schedule. But I would highly recommend, and Liang Laoshi is wonderful!!!

YES! I love learning Chinese, and Liang Lao Shi really made this class enjoyable by carefully picking movies that will interest students. I learned a lot of new terms through the vocab cards we made throughout the seven lessons.
yes, well-suited for heritage learners at the L5 level and a good alternative to the traditional learning style
